awd_abstract_narration:
The ``Geometric Flows and Relativity” summer school and workshop will take place during March 11—March 20, 2024 in Uruguay; the summer school will be held in Montevideo and the workshop in Punta del Este.  The first part of the meeting, the summer school, will consist of three lecture series whose topics will be on mean curvature flow, Ricci flow and applications of geometric flows to mathematical relativity, respectively. The second part of the meeting, a 3-day workshop, will consist of several talks aiming to discuss recent exciting progress in geometric flows and related fields. The goals of this meeting are: (1) Introduce graduate students and early career researchers from the USA, South America and other regions of the world to the field of geometric flows and applications, allowing them to learn about new exciting developments and to have direct contact with more senior researchers; (2) Promote research, by bringing together active leading specialists; and (3) Support the international environment and network by strengthening the collaborations within different institutions, particularly from the USA and South America.

Geometric analysis is one of the most active and exciting areas in pure mathematics today and geometric flows, in particular, have proven to be a powerful tool in the analysis of a large number of important problems in differential geometry, image processing and mathematical physics, leading to a profound impact on each of these fields. They also arise naturally in various physical contexts such as thermomechanics, annealing metals, crystal growth, flame propagation, wearing processes and conformal field theory. Geometric flows are therefore of interest to a diverse group of scientists outside of pure mathematical fields, including applied mathematicians, materials scientists and theoretical physicists. For all these reasons, the area has gained a large international interest to an extent that by now a large network of specialists are present all over the world. This meeting will be an international gathering on this active topic in an area where such events are sparse. 

Meeting’s webpage: http://www.cmat.edu.uy/~mreiris/ssw/SSW.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Geometric Flows and Relativity Meeting: Outcome Report

The "Geometric Flows and Relativity" meeting took place from March 11–20, 2023, in Uruguay. It was organized by Theodora Bourni (University of Tennessee Knoxville) and Martin Reiris (Universidad de la República, Uruguay). The NSF grant supported the participation of 16 individuals from U.S. institutions in this event.

Summary:

The meeting brought together 46 participants from South America, Europe, Australia, and the United States. The event was structured in two phases. The first phase, a summer school, featured three mini-courses covering mean curvature flow, Ricci flow, and applications of geometric flows to general relativity, taught by field experts. Each course consisted of six 1.5-hour sessions. Between the lectures, there were short 5–10 minute presentations by PhD students showcasing their research. Additionally, dedicated discussion sessions allowed students to engage with the lecturers and explore topics further.

The second phase of the event was a workshop, which included 15 research talks on advanced topics related to those covered in the summer school.

Intellectual Merit:

The workshop provided a comprehensive and in-depth introduction to two key geometric flows, as well as their significant applications in general relativity. Many participants were PhD students, who benefitted from expert-led surveys of recent developments and emerging research trends in these areas. The meeting fostered meaningful interactions between students and senior researchers, offering invaluable opportunities for networking and establishing connections for future collaborations. The international nature of the event allowed attendees to broaden their understanding and deepen their research interests, laying the groundwork for long-term academic exchange.

Broader Impact:

This meeting played a crucial role in building a collaborative bridge between the geometry communities of Uruguay and the United States. It offered graduate students and early-career researchers a unique opportunity to engage with leading experts in geometric flows and relativity. Moreover, it promoted the establishment of new relationships between institutions, paving the way for future collaborations and student exchanges. Notes from the lectures, along with most of the research talks, were made available on the conference website, ensuring that the knowledge shared during the event remains accessible to the broader academic community.
